Are you sure you're using the same Sun Java on the 9.04 system as the 
working 8.10 system? (GCJ, in particular, seems to work just enough for 
heritrix to make you think it's OK, before failing in important ways.)

If basic operations are failing but no errors are evident in the web UI, 
there should be clues appearing in the heritrix_out.log -- either at 
startup or when operations fail.

(That Ubuntu has for recent releases defaulted to the the lightweight 
'dash' shell over 'bash' can cause problems for shell scripts, but I 
don't think that's the case here -- we only use a shell script to 
initiall launch, which is working for you.)

- Gordon@ IA

bowser.richard wrote:
> I have been runing the 1.14.3 web crawler under Ubuntu 8.10 for several months.  I just moved on to Ubuntu 9.04, only to find Heritrix's control interface broken here.  The first thing I noticed was that while I can still start Heritrix and get into the WUI console to create jobs, major parts of console functionality are lost. For example, if I try to Shut down Heritrix software I get as far as the "Are you sure?" screen, I can go no further. Whenever I click on "I'm sure, shut it down" - nothing happens.  However, clicking on "Cancel" does cause the request to vanish.  Yet the only way I can shut down Heritrix is by rebooting my system (I haven't tried killing the process. The shutdown script is DOA.)
> 
> Trying to start a job also fails.  I can create a job.  The modules button should take me to the configuration page.  But no, it just returns me to the Jobs page which shows the pending job I'm trying to create.  However, I can click on the "Edit configuration" option, which gets me to the configuration page.  Only problem is then there's no way to get to the "Submit job" button.  I have to use my browser's back button to get to the console window with that tab.  But if I click it Heritrix looses all my configuration options.
> 
> It's obvious that something is upsetting normal script functionality here.  Can somebody help me idenitfy this problem?
> 
> Rich B.
>
